Make anytrees copyable

Now I have a tree and want to iterate upon it, but I do not find the iterator I would need in the doc (https://anytree.readthedocs.io/en/2.8.0/api/anytree.iterators.html).

>>> f = Node("f")
>>> b = Node("b", parent=f)

items.title: `NodeMixin` class should not access the user class special methods.
items.body:
The methods of the `NodeMixin` class should not access the user class special methods.

For instance, the user define a `MyNode` class as bellow:

```python
from anytree import NodeMixin


class MyNode(NodeMixin):
    def __init__(self, name, parent=None, children=None):
        super(MyNode, self).__init__()
        self.name = name
        self.parent = parent
        if children:
            self.children = children
```

In this class, the used can implement some special methods, like ``__eq__`` or ``__len__``,
which can have a specific meaning not related to the Tree structure.
A good exemple could be a `NodeMixin` subclass which also implements `collections.abc.Mapping`:


```python
import collections

from anytree import NodeMixin


class MyMapping(NodeMixin, collections.abc.Mapping):
    def __init__(self, name, parent=None, children=None):
        super(MyMapping, self).__init__()
        self.name = name
        self.parent = parent
        if children:
            self.children = children

    def __iter__(self):
        for child in self.children:
            yield child
            for item in child:
                yield item

    def __len__(self):
        return len(list(iter(self)))

    def __getitem__(self, name):
        for child in self:
            if child.name == name:
                return child
        raise KeyError(name)
```

In this example, the `NodeMixin` class shouldn't make any call to `__iter__`, `__len__` or `__getitem__`.

To avoid that, the `NodeMixin` class should respect the following rules:

- Do not compare nodes by value but by reference.
  In other words, the `NodeMixin` class should not use `==` or `!=` but compare nodes with the `id()` function.
  Comparison could be done with the `is` or `is not` operator. Avoid using `in` or `not in`.

- Do not use truth value testing to check if a node is "empty".
  The `NodeMixin` class should not `if node`, `if not node`, `while node` nor `while not node`.
  Instead, it must compare the node with `None` like this: `if node is not None`, `if node is None`,
  `while node is not None` or `while node is None`.

- Do not presume that nodes are hashable.
  The `NodeMixin` class should not store nodes in `set` or `dict`.
  Instead, it can store node IDs using the `id()` function.

Currently, the following unit test fails:

```python
class TestMyMapping(unittest.TestCase):
    def setUp(self):
        super(TestMyMapping, self).setUp()
        self.root1 = MyMapping("root1")
        self.child1 = MyMapping("child1", parent=self.root1)
        self.child2a = MyMapping("child2a", parent=self.child1)
        self.child2b = MyMapping("child2b", parent=self.child1)

    def test_iter(self):
        expected_list = [self.child1, self.child2a, self.child2b]
        for actual, expected in zip(iter(self.root1), expected_list):
            self.assertIs(actual, expected)

    def test_len(self):
        self.assertEqual(len(self.root1), 3)

    def test_getitem(self):
        self.assertIs(self.root1["child1"], self.child1)
        self.assertIs(self.root1["child2a"], self.child2a)
        self.assertIs(self.root1["child2b"], self.child2b)
        with self.assertRaises(KeyError):
            _ = self.root1["missing"]
```

The error is raised in the `setUp` function:

```python
Traceback (most recent call last):
  ...
  File "path/to/anytree/tests/test_node_mapping.py", line 40, in setUp
    self.child2b = MyMapping("child2b", parent=self.child1)
  File "path/to/anytree/tests/test_node_mapping.py", line 12, in __init__
    self.parent = parent
  File "path/to/anytree/anytree/node/nodemixin.py", line 133, in parent
    self.__check_loop(value)
  File "path/to/anytree/anytree/node/nodemixin.py", line 142, in __check_loop
    if self in node.iter_path_reverse():
  File "path/to/lib/_collections_abc.py", line 687, in __eq__
    return dict(self.items()) == dict(other.items())
  File "path/to/lib/_collections_abc.py", line 744, in __iter__
    yield (key, self._mapping[key])
  File "path/to/anytree/tests/test_node_mapping.py", line 31, in __getitem__
    raise KeyError(name)
KeyError: <test_node_mapping.MyMapping object at ...>
```

items.title: fastcache warning should be ImportWarning, not UserWarning?
items.body: Semantics, but shouldn't ImportWarning be used when attempting to import fastcache?  Currently, all my programs that use anytree now emit the warning to stderr, which is information that is probably spurious to users, and only of use to the code developers.

items.title: Caching searches may be dangerous -- should be off by default?
items.body:
in [our project](https://github.com/opesci/devito) we use `anytree` to build abstract syntax trees. The leaves of our trees contain symbolic objects, which in turn carry data (think of it as numpy array, which can be pretty big). 

This leads to memory leaks -- when such symbolic objects disappear from user code, one would expect that the corresponding data is freed, but now with the newest `anytree` this isn't the case. Our CI caught this issue. 

Any thoughts ?

items.body:
Hi,

Thank you for this project, it's really helpful.

I don't know if this is a known issue or if it's written somewhere in the docs, so forgive me if this is misplaced.

I've run into an issue with the following code:
```python
from anytree import Node
from anytree.exporter import DotExporter

root = Node(1)
s0 = Node("sub0", parent=root)
s0b = Node("sub0B", parent=s0)

DotExporter(root).to_dotfile("tree.dot")
```

It gives the following output:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "test.py", line 8, in <module>
    DotExporter(root).to_dotfile("tree.dot")
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/anytree/exporter/dotexporter.py", line 214, in to_dotfile
```

items.title: DotExporter doesn't escape backslashes
items.body:
The following fails, because backslashes are not escaped.  For background, see the similar issue [DotExporter doesn't escape quotes](https://github.com/c0fec0de/anytree/issues/69#issuecomment-462547683).  

The following code
```
from anytree import Node 
from anytree.exporter import DotExporter 
n = Node(r'6\"') 
for line in DotExporter(n): 
    print(line) 
DotExporter(n).to_picture('fail.svg')
```
results in
```
digraph tree {
    "6\\"";
}
Error: /tmp/tmpkloz8shq: syntax error in line 2 near ''
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
CalledProcessError                        Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-16-254eea0428d3> in <module>
      4 for line in DotExporter(n):
      5     print(line)
----> 6 DotExporter(n).to_picture('fail.svg')

~/anaconda3/envs/anytree/lib/python3.7/site-packages/anytree/exporter/dotexporter.py in to_picture(self, filename)
    230             dotfile.flush()
    231             cmd = ["dot", dotfilename, "-T", fileformat, "-o", filename]
--> 232             check_call(cmd)
    233         try:
    234             remove(dotfilename)

~/anaconda3/envs/anytree/lib/python3.7/subprocess.py in check_call(*popenargs, **kwargs)
    345         if cmd is None:
    346             cmd = popenargs[0]
--> 347         raise CalledProcessError(retcode, cmd)
    348     return 0
    349 

CalledProcessError: Command '['dot', '/tmp/tmpkloz8shq', '-T', 'svg', '-o', 'fail.svg']' returned non-zero exit status 1.
```
I think you can (at least mostly) fix this issue by changing [this line](https://github.com/c0fec0de/anytree/blob/9c3d4cfbb2bad059f2ebe4420ea4eeb02849c497/anytree/exporter/dotexporter.py#L241) to 
```
return str.replace("\\", "\\\\").replace("\"", "\\\"")
```

items.title: AbstractIter is not quite a proper python iterator.
items.body:
`AbstractIter.__iter__` always returns a new iterator.
consider
```
nodes = anytree.PreOrderIter(root)
next(nodes) # returns root
for node in nodes: # new iterator is reset
    node # root again
```
This is not the expected operation of an iterator but is easily fixed.

Note that `AbstractIter.__init` returns a proper iterator and therefore 
`iter(anytree.PreOrderIter(root))` is one.

items.title: Adding different properties to Nodes
items.body:
Please extend this library so that we can _add different custom properties to the nodes in the tree in python dictionary format and can be able to fetch/operate on them_.
for example, in your tree given in README.rst file, If we would have added the nodes in this way:

```
from anytree import Node, RenderTree
udo = Node("Udo", attributes={age=45, sex='F', sibling_count=3, credit_score=700})
marc = Node("Marc", parent=udo)
lian = Node("Lian", parent=marc, attributes={husband='Garry'})
dan = Node("Dan", parent=udo, attributes={salary='$2500', age=25, sex='M'})
jet = Node("Jet", parent=dan)
jan = Node("Jan", parent=dan)
joe = Node("Joe", parent=dan)
```

The tree generated will be as:
```
Udo {age=45, sex='M', sibling_count=3, credit_score=700}
├── Marc
│   └── Lian {husband='Garry'}
└── Dan {salary='$2500', age=25, sex='M'}
    ├── Jet
    ├── Jan
    └── Joe

```
Further, we can set/get/clear different attributes from the dictionary later as needed as we can do in any python dictionary.

**To summarize**, we can attach different python dictionary to each node and can perform dictionary operations on the attached dictionary.

items.title: DotExporter doesn't escape quotes
items.body:
Here is a MWE where `DotExporter` doesn't escape quotes, causing `to_picture()` to fail:

```
from anytree import Node
from anytree.exporter import DotExporter
n = Node('6"')
for line in DotExporter(n):
    print(line)
DotExporter(n).to_picture('fail.svg')
```
which produces
```
digraph tree {
    "6"";
}
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
CalledProcessError                        Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-21-1daf819531d3> in <module>()
      5 for line in DotExporter(n):
      6     print(line)
----> 7 DotExporter(n).to_picture('fail.svg')

~/anaconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/anytree/exporter/dotexporter.py in to_picture(self, filename)
    231             cmd = ["dot", dotfile.name, "-T", fileformat, "-o", filename]
--> 232             check_call(cmd)

~/anaconda3/lib/python3.6/subprocess.py in check_call(*popenargs, **kwargs)
    289         if cmd is None:
    290             cmd = popenargs[0]
--> 291         raise CalledProcessError(retcode, cmd)
    292     return 0
    293 

CalledProcessError: Command '['dot', '/tmp/tmpcdfyz4p4', '-T', 'svg', '-o', 'fail.svg']' returned non-zero exit status 1.
```
Reproducing this on the command line shows the following error:
```
Error: tmpfile: syntax error in line 2 scanning a quoted string (missing endquote? longer than 16384?)
String starting:";
}
```
The proper way to escape a quote in DOT seems to be with a backslash:
```
def nodenamefunc(node):
    return node.name.replace('"', r'\"')
for line in DotExporter(n, nodenamefunc=nodenamefunc):
    print(line)
DotExporter(n, nodenamefunc=nodenamefunc).to_picture('success.svg')
```
which produces:
```
digraph tree {
    "6\"";
}
```
The corresponding .svg file contains `<text>6"</text>` which correctly renders to `6"`.  

Unfortunately, even with this tweak, now the `\` character is not properly escaped, so if we do the above on `n = Node(r'6\"')` then it will break.  (The replacement rule leads to the string `r'6\\"'` so that the double-backslash turns into an escape sequence, and the `"` is left unescaped, leading to the previous error.)

Have you looked at [pydot](https://github.com/pydot/pydot)?  It seems to be under active development, but there are quite a few open issues.

items.title: "self.path" attribute is incomplete in "Node._post_attach" definition slot.
items.body:
Hi,

The `self.path` attribute is incomplete when accessed from the `Node._post_attach` definition slot:

```python
from anytree import Node

class MyNode(Node):
    def __init__(self, name, parent=None, **kwargs):
        super(MyNode, self).__init__(name, parent, **kwargs)

    def _post_attach(self, parent):
        print(self.parent)
        print(self.path)


node_a = MyNode('A')
node_b = MyNode('B', node_a)
node_c = MyNode('C', node_b)
node_d = MyNode('D', node_c)

print(node_d.path)
```

``` python
None
(MyNode('/B'),)
None
(MyNode('/C'),)
None
(MyNode('/D'),)
(MyNode('/A'), MyNode('/A/B'), MyNode('/A/B/C'), MyNode('/A/B/C/D'))
```

This is surprising from an API usage perspective as you would expect `self.parent` and `self.path` to be representing the state of the given node after being parented. It would probably worth defining what *attaching* exactly means.

Cheers,

Thomas

items.title: Naming of the "detach" and "attach" slots.
items.body:
Hi,

I wanted to start talking about the current naming convention of the *detach* and *attach* slots:

- `_pre_detach`
- `_post_detach`
- `_pre_attach`
- `_post_attach`

In theory and accordingly to [PEP 8](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0008/), the fact they start with an underscore implies for seasoned Python developers that they are part of the recognised _private_ part of the API:

> Use one leading underscore only for non-public methods and instance variables.

This is not a major problem but it makes me a bit uncomfortable.

As a side note last week when we were discussing about some of work I have done leveraging *anytree*, a co-worker asked me why the `_pre_detach` definitions in my code were named like so, told him I could not do much about it and it was the way *anytree* was exposing the hooks.

I reckon that it would be great to name them in a way that it is clear that they are part of the public API of *anytree*.

items.title: "AttributeError" exception raised when accessing instantiation time "kwarg" in attach callbacks.
items.body:
Hi,

An `AttributeError` exception is being raised when I try to access an instantiation time `kwarg` in the attach callbacks.

Here is a reproducible example:

``` python
from anytree import Node

class MyNode(Node):
    def __init__(self, name, parent=None, **kwargs):
        super(MyNode, self).__init__(name, parent, **kwargs)

    def _post_attach(self, parent):
        print(self.my_attribute)


node_a = MyNode('A')
node_b = MyNode('B', node_a, my_attribute=True)
print(node_b)
```

and the traceback:

```python
AttributeErrorTraceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-22-94f8f5bf82a3> in <module>()
     12 
     13 node_a = MyNode('A')
---> 14 node_b = MyNode('B', node_a, my_attribute=True)
     15 print(node_b)

<ipython-input-22-94f8f5bf82a3> in __init__(self, name, parent, **kwargs)
      5 class MyNode(AbstractNode):
      6     def __init__(self, name, parent=None, **kwargs):
----> 7         super(MyNode, self).__init__(name, parent, **kwargs)
      8 
      9     def _post_attach(self, parent):

<ipython-input-18-7c2ada3c82ac> in __init__(self, name, parent, **kwargs)
      8             kwargs['attribute'] = True
      9 
---> 10         super(AbstractNode, self).__init__(name, parent, **kwargs)
     11 
     12 class ConcreteNode(AbstractNode):

C:\Users\thomas\Packages\anytree\2.2.1\anytree\Lib\site-packages\anytree\node.pyc in __init__(self, name, parent, **kwargs)
    429         """
    430         self.name = name
--> 431         self.parent = parent
    432         self.__dict__.update(kwargs)
    433 

C:\Users\thomas\Packages\anytree\2.2.1\anytree\Lib\site-packages\anytree\node.pyc in parent(self, value)
    100             self.__check_loop(value)
    101             self.__detach(parent)
--> 102             self.__attach(value)
    103         else:
    104             # keep parent

C:\Users\thomas\Packages\anytree\2.2.1\anytree\Lib\site-packages\anytree\node.pyc in __attach(self, parent)
    128         assert self not in parentchildren, "Tree internal data is corrupt."
    129         parentchildren.append(self)
--> 130         self._post_attach(parent)
    131 
    132     @property

<ipython-input-22-94f8f5bf82a3> in _post_attach(self, parent)
      8 
      9     def _post_attach(self, parent):
---> 10         print(self.my_attribute)
     11 
     12 

AttributeError: 'MyNode' object has no attribute 'my_attribute'
```

The reason is because `Node.__dict__` gets updated only after accessing the `Node.parent` property here:

https://github.com/c0fec0de/anytree/blob/master/anytree/node.py#L432

Moving the statement before fixes the issue.

items.title: Iterators can not be used with next()
items.body:
When using the iterators for the tree objects, I realized that Python (2.7.13) does not recognize them as iterators, presumably because there is no ```__next__()``` method:

```python
>>> my_node1, my_node2, my_node3 = Node("a"), Node("b"), Node("c")
>>> my_node2.parent = my_node1
>>> my_iter = tree_iter.PreOrderIter(my_node1)
>>> next(my_iter)
Traceback (most recent call last):
      ...
TypeError: PreOrderIter object is not an iterator
```

Instead, I have to wrap it in ```iter()``` to work:
```python
>>> my_iter = iter(tree_iter.PreOrderIter(my_node1))
>>> next(my_iter)
Node('/a')
```

Is this intended behavior?

items.title: Setting a node's children simultaneously
items.body: I find it sometimes useful to set the children of a node simultaneously all in one step. This is motivated by trees--or, more precisely, their interpretation--that can be invalidated by adding children sequentially; however, in order to check whether a particular set of children would result in a valid tree, I need to be able to add all children at once. Therefore, I extended this class by a setter method for the `children` attribute, as well as hooks  `_pre_detach_children`, `_post_detach_children`, `_pre_attach_children`, and `_post_attach_children`. Any interest in incorporating this?

items.title: Inconsistent state after LoopError
items.body:
If a node's parent is changed, the node will be detached (i.e. its parent's children list is updated), but the parent of the corresponding node remains unchanged; if the __check_loop method now raises a LoopError which is captured, the tree becomes inconsistent and the node cannot be re-attached to its previous parent because of lines 102 to 104 in node.py:

```python
        elif parent is not value:
            # detach, check_loop, attach ...
        else:
            # keep parent
            pass
```

Therefore, I suggest to add the following line to node.py:
```python
elif parent is not value:
     # change parent node
     self.__detach(parent)
     # reset parent
     self._parent = None
     self.__check_loop(value)
     self.__attach(value)
```

Like this, a node has a defined parent after it has been detached, even if an error occurred.

Even more elegant would be 
```python
elif parent is not value:
     # reset parent
     self.parent = None
     self.__check_loop(value)
     self.__attach(value)
```
However, the former solution can be implemented in a non-intrusive way by modifying `_post_detach`.

items.title: glob doesn't work for same attribute value nodes
items.body:
Since __get_nodemap returns OrderedDict, it requires that the search by part will be unique, and hence doesn't allow searching for more than one node with the same value.

E.g.

```
d = Node("parent")
child_1 = Node("child_1", parent=d, value="5")
child_2 = Node("child_2", parent=d, value="5")
r = Resolver("value")
nodes = r.glob(d, "5")
```

will return only the last found node.
